üé® GitHub Repository Social Preview Setup

Follow these steps to make your GitHub repository look professional and attractive!

Step 1: Add Social Preview Image

Convert the assets/social-preview.svg to PNG and add it to your repository:

  1. Open assets/social-preview.svg in a browser or design tool (Figma, Canva, etc.)
  2. Export as PNG at 1280x640 pixels
  3. Name it social-preview.png
  4. Place it in the assets/ folder or repository root

Quick conversion tools:

  • CloudConvert SVG to PNG
  • AConvert SVG to PNG

Step 2: Update Repository Settings on GitHub

  1. Go to your repository on GitHub
  2. Click Settings tab
  3. Scroll to About section
  4. Add these details:
Name: BMC Remedy RAG Agent
Description: ü§ñ On-premise RAG agent for BMC Remedy ITSM with local embeddings and semantic search | Java 17 ‚Ä¢ Spring Boot ‚Ä¢ LangChain4j ‚Ä¢ pgvector
Website: https://your-docs-site.com (optional)

Step 3: Add Repository Topics

In the same Settings page, scroll to Topics and add these (max 20):

rag, java, spring-boot, langchain4j, postgresql, pgvector,
itsm, bmc-remedy, semantic-search, llm, embeddings,
vector-database, generative-ai, microservices, docker,
on-premise, air-gapped, react, typescript, enterprise

Step 4: Set Repository Logo (Optional)

GitHub doesn't natively support custom repository logos, but you can:

  • Organization: If under an organization, set the organization avatar
  • Social Image: The social preview will be used when sharing
  • README Badge: Add the logo to your README:
<img src="assets/logo.svg" alt="BMC Remedy RAG Agent" width="200"/>

Step 5: Enable GitHub Features

In Settings, enable these features:

  • ‚úÖ Issues - For bug tracking and feature requests
  • ‚úÖ Discussions - For community Q&A
  • ‚úÖ Wikis - For detailed documentation (optional)
  • ‚úÖ Actions - For CI/CD (if needed)
  • ‚ùå Projects - Unless you use project boards

üéØ Tips for a Professional Repository

  • Badges in README: Add build status, version, and license badges
  • Screenshots: Add GIFs or images showing the application in action
  • Contributing: Add a CONTRIBUTING.md file
  • Changelog: Maintain a CHANGELOG.md for version history
  • License: Add a LICENSE file (even if proprietary)
